channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Biden Is Now an Uneasy Champion on Abortion. Activists Are Still Wary.
item.description: A practicing Catholic, President Biden has long sought a middle ground on abortion. But activists see the decision to overturn Roe v. Wade as a sign that Democrats have tiptoed too carefully around the issue.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: For five decades, President Biden has drawn on his faith to shape his political identity.

item.title: Some Women Turn to Self-Managed Abortion as Access Recedes
item.description: Information and medications needed to end a pregnancy are increasingly available outside the health care system.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: Who Killed Tair Rada? Inside Israel’s True Crime Obsession
item.description: A TV documentary upended a murder case and captivated the nation. But its sensational theories might also be distorting justice.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Margalit

item.title: After China’s Military Drills, Options Narrow to Win Over Taiwan
item.description: The exercises were designed to deter Taiwan from moving further away from Beijing, but they also indicated how few policy carrots China has.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and John Liu
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: People lined up near the Hsinchu Military Air Base in Taiwan on Friday.

item.title: Guadalcanal Anniversary Marked by a Kennedy
item.description: At a ceremony to mark the 80th anniversary of a crucial battle in the Pacific, two daughters of men who served there reflected on the lessons of war.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Caroline Kennedy, U.S. ambassador to Australia and daughter of John F. Kennedy, presented medals on Sunday to Nelma Ane and John Koloni, the descendants of men who saved her father during World War II.

item.title: Liz Cheney Is Ready to Lose. But She’s Not Ready to Quit.
item.description: The Republican says her crusade to stop Donald J. Trump will continue — even if she loses her primary next week. Restoring a “very sick” G.O.P. will take years, she says, “if it can be healed.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin
item.media:credit: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Liz Cheney with supporters in Cheyenne, Wyo.

item.title: Pitching G.O.P. on Gay Marriage Bill, Tammy Baldwin Leaves Nothing to Chance
item.description: The second-term Democrat was the first openly gay woman elected to Congress. Now she is leading the effort to rally Republican support for legislation that would protect marriage equality nationwide.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Tammy Baldwin is helming the effort to win over the 10 Republican senators whose backing is necessary to win passage of the Respect for Marriage Act.

item.title: Colombia’s First Black Vice President Spotlights Afro-Caribbean Fashion
item.description: The wardrobe of Francia Márquez, Colombia’s first Black vice president, is the creation of a young designer at the center of an Afro-Colombian fashion explosion.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: When he’s not in class, Esteban Sinisterra Paz sews the vice president’s outfits in a windowless room in his small second-story apartment in Cali.

item.title: Amnesty International Assessment That Ukraine ‘Put Civilians in Harm’s Way’ Stirs Outrage
item.description: The human rights group accused the Ukrainian military of establishing bases and weapons systems in school and hospitals.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: An apartment building heavily damaged by Russian attacks in Kostiantynivka, Ukraine, on Friday. Some experts fear a new report will give Russia an excuse to further target civilian areas.

item.title: At Least 4 Players on Alabama’s ’60s Football Teams Had CTE
item.description: At least four fixtures of Alabama’s great teams of the 1960s had chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., at their deaths. Researchers expect it in other players, too.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: The New York Times; photo by the University of Alabama

item.title: 3 Days. 68 Kids. Snapshots of Summer on Coney Island.
item.description: The New York Times for Kids visited the quirky but classic destination.
item.dc:creator: Josh Ocampo and Caroline Tompkins

item.title: How Is Senator Ron Johnson Still Competitive?
item.description: He has a way of winning Wisconsin Senate races in spite of his weird behavior. Democrats see ousting him this fall as key to keeping the Senate.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images

item.title: Hey, Joe, Don’t Give It a Go
item.description: Rest on your laurels, and don’t run for re-election, Mr. President.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Evan Vucci

item.title: I Didn’t Want It to Be True, but the Medium Really Is the Message
item.description: How we look matters as much as what we see.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.category: How to Do Nothing: Resisting the Attention Economy (Book)
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Pelle Cass

item.title: The New Politics of Abortion
item.description: The pro-life movement needs to learn the art of the possible.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Marco Bello/Reuters

item.title: Hulu’s ‘The Bear’ and the Restaurant Industry’s Long Overdue Reckoning
item.description: The Hulu drama is resonating partly because it shows workers demanding a better workplace, which is happening in the restaurant industry and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Saru Jayaraman

item.title: The Case for Longtermism
item.description: We are living through an extraordinary and precarious chapter in humanity’s story.
item.dc:creator: William MacAskill
item.media:credit: Tim Enthoven

item.title: Return to Office: Young Workers Shouldn’t Stay Remote Forever
item.description: Many offices are desolate, open plan landscapes dotted with individuals staring at screens, headphones on. It doesn’t have to be that way.
item.dc:creator: Edith Cooper
item.media:credit: Golden Cosmos

item.title: Bill Gates: A Clean Energy Future is in the Hands of Congress
item.description: The Inflation Reduction Act may be the single-most important piece of climate legislation in American history.
item.dc:creator: Bill Gates
item.media:credit: Cj Gunther/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: Travel Troubles
item.description: Two Times reporters answered your travel questions to help you navigate this hectic vacation season.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Lluis Gene/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘Why Was Joshua Held for More Than Two Years for Someone Else’s Crimes?’
item.description: Honolulu incarcerated the wrong man for more than two years — a miscarriage of justice that shows the cruel inadequacy of America’s approach to mental health.
item.dc:creator: Robert Kolker, Jack D’Isidoro, Marion Lozano, John Woo, Elisheba Ittoop and Zachary Mouton

item.title: Five Years of the Second Avenue Subway
item.description: Journey to the Upper East Side for Thai specialties, “jewel” rice and South African wine.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson
item.media:credit: Regina Chuikova/Lashevet Restaurant
item.media:description: The new restaurant Lashevet serves food inspired by the cuisines of Israel, Lebanon and Morocco, like this beef skewer.

item.title: Amid the Pandemic, the Rise of the Single-Issue Parent: The Week in Narrated Articles
item.description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

item.title: Officials Wrestle With Whether to Allow New Monkeypox Vaccination Strategy
item.description: A new way of injecting monkeypox vaccine could stretch the nation’s supply of shots, but some experts argue that the approach has not been sufficiently studied.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vaccination line at the Central Harlem Sexual Health Clinic in New York on Thursday. Federal health officials are concerned that the monkeypox outbreak, which is now almost entirely confined to men who have sex with men, will spill over into the general population.

item.title: In the Kenyan Election, a Fierce Battle to Lead an African Powerhouse
item.description: Kenyans vote for a new president on Tuesday, ending a heated race that shows why, in a troubled region, the East African nation matters more than ever.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Baz Ratner/Reuters

item.title: London’s Trellick Tower and a Development Debate
item.description: Residents of Trellick Tower, a 1972 public housing block, fought to stop a development project they said would undermine the building’s integrity. But they fear the reprieve might be only temporary.
item.dc:creator: Saskia Solomon
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: Will One Moldy Berry Ruin the Rest?
item.description: Here’s what the experts say.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About Polio: Vaccines, Symptoms and How It Spreads
item.description: A recent case in a New York suburb has reignited concerns over the disease.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: CDC, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An illustration depicts a polio virus particle.

item.title: Why Daydreaming Is Actually Good For Your Brain
item.description: Letting your mind wander can benefit the brain, researchers say.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Guillem Casasus

item.title: Near Castle Ruins, a Wedding with a Dash of ‘Game of Thrones’
item.description: After matching on Bumble, Kristen Sanders, a police officer, and April Hill, a makeup artist, began a courtship that ended with a marriage ceremony overlooking Dunluce Castle, in Northern Ireland.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Block
item.media:credit: Therese Aherne for The New York Times
item.media:description: April Hill, left, and Kristen Sanders were married June 18 at a private property in Bushmills, Northern Ireland, near the ruins of Dunluce Castle.
